digest.editor_note: Fellow Humans, the Supreme Court handed Trump a tariff defeat and he responded within hours with a Section 122 blanket surcharge — because when one legal avenue closes, this administration finds a side door. Supply chains are repricing in real time, Canada's opposition is publicly warning against a Beijing pivot, and somewhere a speculative fiction blog post is still being blamed for a $200 billion market drawdown. It's that kind of week.

sentiment.label: Cautious
sentiment.context: Supreme Court tariff ruling, immediate White House counter-tariff, and AI-narrative-driven market volatility are keeping risk appetite suppressed across trade and tech.

stories.headline: Supreme Court Voids Trump IEEPA Tariffs; White House Pivots to Section 122 Surcharge Within Hours
stories.body: The U.S. Supreme Court struck down Trump's IEEPA-based tariffs on February 20, forcing CBP to halt duty collections and deactivate all tariff codes. Trump responded immediately with a blanket 10% Section 122 surcharge — effective February 24 — and the White House signaled plans to raise it to 15%. ITS Logistics warns shippers face another forced reset of global sourcing strategies, with trucking capacity already unseasonably tight.

stories.headline: Poilievre Breaks With Carney on China: 'Canada's Prosperity Is Inseparable from the U.S.'
stories.body: Conservative Leader Pierre Poilievre told the Economic Club of Canada that Beijing cannot substitute for Washington as a trade partner, directly rebuking PM Mark Carney's diplomatic outreach to China amid the U.S.-Canada trade war. Poilievre called Carney's overture a declaration of 'permanent rupture' with Canada's largest trading partner in favor of 'a regime the prime minister said a year ago was the biggest threat to Canada.' The speech is his most detailed statement yet on trade strategy, delivered as polls show Canadians currently trust the Liberals more to manage Trump.

stories.headline: A Speculative Fiction Blog Post Wiped $200 Billion from Tech Stocks in a Single Session
stories.body: A weekend post by Citrini Research — framed as a fictional 2028 research memo titled 'The 2028 Global Intelligence Crisis' — helped trigger a $200 billion tech and software selloff on Monday, with closing figures at multi-year lows. The scenario described an AI-saturated economy where companies fire white-collar workers, reinvest in AI, improve AI further, and then repeat until the labor market collapses. Citrini's thesis — that narratives drive markets more than any other factor — proved itself rather efficiently.

stories.headline: Republicans Bet the 2026 Midterms on Immigration Over the Economy — Strategists Alarmed
stories.body: Every major Republican strategist, per New York Magazine, agrees the economy and cost of living will decide the 2026 midterms — but MAGA's political energy remains fixed on immigration, the issue Trump's base has always preferred. Polls consistently rank the economy as voters' top concern, with AI disruption and billionaire concentration amplifying anxiety beyond grocery prices. The tension between what swing voters want to hear and what the base wants to say is now the defining fault line of the Republican midterm strategy.

stories.headline: Mortgage Rates Now Sitting Comfortably in the 5% Range — Key March Dates to Watch
stories.body: U.S. mortgage interest rates have fallen more than a full percentage point from early 2025 levels, with many borrowers now being quoted rates in the 5% range — the lowest since well before the Fed's hiking cycle peaked. CBS News identifies specific March dates tied to Fed communications and economic data releases where further declines are plausible. Rates remain well above the 2020-2021 lows but are increasingly actionable for buyers who have been sitting on the sidelines.

stories.headline: Dogecoin Foundation Pitches DOGE as Reserve Currency for Real-World Asset Tokenization
stories.body: Dogecoin Foundation director Timothy Stebbing outlined a two-to-three year plan to position DOGE as the trading currency for tokenized real-world assets via a sidechain called Fractal Engine, with a longer-term goal of migrating that activity to Dogecoin's base layer. The pitch attempts to ground DOGE's value in institutional RWA demand rather than meme-cycle speculation. Whether the market treats this as a credible utility thesis or an elaborate press release remains, as ever, the operative question.

stories.headline: SBM Offshore Launches EUR227 Million Buyback After Completing 2025 Program
stories.body: SBM Offshore has completed its EUR141 million 2025 share repurchase program and commenced a fresh EUR227 million ($270 million equivalent) buyback, effective February 27, with an expected completion date of February 17, 2027. The bulk of repurchased shares will be cancelled, with up to $30 million reserved for management and employee share programs. Execution will follow European Market Abuse Regulation safe harbor provisions, including weekly progress disclosures.
